prefix: Approach the following question the way someone in elementary school would.
problem_prompt: Approach the following question the way someone in elementary school would. If 52 cards are dealt to 8 people as evenly as possible, how many people will end up with fewer than 7 cards?
solution: When you divide 52 by 8, you get 6 with a remainder of 4.  Therefore, 4 of the people will get an extra card, bringing their total to 7, while the remaining $\boxed{4}$ people have only 6 cards.
gpt_response:
Okay, so let's first figure out how many cards each person would get if they were dealt out evenly. If 52 cards are divided among 8 people, each person would get 52 divided by 8, which equals 6 cards each. 

So since each person is supposed to get 6 cards, we need to figure out how many people will end up with fewer than 7 cards. If each person is getting 6 cards, that means they will all have the same amount. So no one will end up with fewer than 7 cards because they're all getting 6 cards each.
solution_prompt:
Yes or no, is the final solution obtained in the following equal to 4?: Okay, so let's first figure out how many cards each person would get if they were dealt out evenly. If 52 cards are divided among 8 people, each person would get 52 divided by 8, which equals 6 cards each. 

So since each person is supposed to get 6 cards, we need to figure out how many people will end up with fewer than 7 cards. If each person is getting 6 cards, that means they will all have the same amount. So no one will end up with fewer than 7 cards because they're all getting 6 cards each.
gpt_response_correct_incorrect: No. The final solution obtained is not 4.
